Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"To slacken the tempo would mean falling behind. And those who fall behind get beaten. But we do not want to be beaten. No, we refuse to be beaten! One feature of the history of old Russia was the continual beatings she suffered because of her backwardness. She was beaten by the Mongol khans. She was beaten by the Turkish beys. She was beaten by the Swedish feudal lords. She was beaten by the Polish and Lithuanian gentry. She was beaten by the British and French capitalists. She was beaten by the Japanese barons. All beat her––because of her backwardness, because of her military backwardness, cultural backwardness, political backwardness, industrial backwardness, agricultural backwardness. They beat her because it was profitable and could be done with impunity. You remember the words of the pre-revolutionary poet: "You are poor and abundant, mighty and impotent, Mother Russia." Those gentlemen were quite familiar with the verses of the old poet. They beat her, saying: "You are abundant," so one can enrich oneself at your expense. They beat her, saying: "You are poor and impotent," so you can be beaten and plundered with impunity. Such is the law of the exploiters––to beat the backward and the weak. It is the jungle law of capitalism. You are backward, you are weak––therefore you are wrong; hence you can be beaten and enslaved. You are mighty––therefore you are right; hence we must be wary of you.
That is why we must no longer lag behind."
Joseph Stalin, speech delivered at the first All-Union Conference of Leading Personnel of Socialist Industry, February 4, 1931
The reference to the "continual beatings" most directly supports which of the following decisions in later Soviet foreign policy?
B: The creation of the Warsaw Pact
C: The imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine against anti-Soviet protesters in Europe
D: The declaration of war against Japan at the end of World War II
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [C].  The correct answer is [C] The imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine against anti-Soviet protesters in Europe. The passage discusses how Russia was continually beaten by other countries due to its backwardness and weakness. This idea of being beaten by stronger powers is reflected in the Brezhnev Doctrine, which stated that the Soviet Union had the right to intervene in any Eastern European country that threatened the stability of the Soviet bloc. This was seen as a way for the Soviet Union to assert its dominance and prevent any potential threats from weaker countries. The other options do not directly relate to the idea of being beaten by stronger powers.
explanationstyle1: I am not completely sure that the answer is [C] because the passage does not explicitly mention any specific events or decisions in Soviet foreign policy. It only discusses the history of Russia being beaten by other countries due to its backwardness and the need for the Soviet Union to catch up and no longer lag behind. However, the mention of the "jungle law of capitalism" and the exploitation of weaker nations could potentially support the imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine against anti-Soviet protesters in Europe. Therefore, while I am leaning towards [C], I am not completely certain and the answer could also potentially be [B] or [A].
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [C] because the reference to "continual beatings" in the speech by Joseph Stalin suggests a sense of vulnerability and fear of being dominated by stronger powers. This fear of being beaten and exploited due to their backwardness is likely to have influenced the Soviet Union's decision to impose the Brezhnev Doctrine, which aimed to prevent any anti-Soviet movements or protests in Eastern Europe. By asserting their dominance and control over these countries, the Soviet Union could avoid being beaten and exploited by other powers. Additionally, the mention of being wary of a powerful country also supports the idea of creating alliances, such as the Warsaw Pact, to protect against potential aggression. Therefore, the reference to "continual beatings" in the speech most directly supports the decision to impose the Brezhnev Doctrine against anti-Soviet protesters in Europe.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [C] because the reference to "continual beatings" in the speech by Joseph Stalin highlights the vulnerability and weakness of old Russia due to its backwardness. This vulnerability and weakness were exploited by other countries, leading to repeated defeats and subjugation. Problem: This question refers to the following information.
"To slacken the tempo would mean falling behind. And those who fall behind get beaten. But we do not want to be beaten. No, we refuse to be beaten! One feature of the history of old Russia was the continual beatings she suffered because of her backwardness. She was beaten by the Mongol khans. She was beaten by the Turkish beys. She was beaten by the Swedish feudal lords. She was beaten by the Polish and Lithuanian gentry. She was beaten by the British and French capitalists. She was beaten by the Japanese barons. All beat her––because of her backwardness, because of her military backwardness, cultural backwardness, political backwardness, industrial backwardness, agricultural backwardness. They beat her because it was profitable and could be done with impunity. You remember the words of the pre-revolutionary poet: "You are poor and abundant, mighty and impotent, Mother Russia." Those gentlemen were quite familiar with the verses of the old poet. They beat her, saying: "You are abundant," so one can enrich oneself at your expense. They beat her, saying: "You are poor and impotent," so you can be beaten and plundered with impunity. Such is the law of the exploiters––to beat the backward and the weak. It is the jungle law of capitalism. You are backward, you are weak––therefore you are wrong; hence you can be beaten and enslaved. You are mighty––therefore you are right; hence we must be wary of you.
That is why we must no longer lag behind."
Joseph Stalin, speech delivered at the first All-Union Conference of Leading Personnel of Socialist Industry, February 4, 1931
The reference to the "continual beatings" most directly supports which of the following decisions in later Soviet foreign policy?
Choose from the following options:
[A] The invasion of Afghanistan
[B] The creation of the Warsaw Pact
[C] The imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine against anti-Soviet protesters in Europe
[D] The declaration of war against Japan at the end of World War II.
The answer you give is [C]
Write an explanation why you are not sure that the answer is [C]. In your explanation, mention that you are not sure and include the answer. Start with "I am":

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"MAHATMA GANDHI'S MESSAGE.
REMAIN NON-VIOLENT
The following message was sent by Mahatma Gandhi from Waltair:—
Maulana Mohamed AH was arrested at Waltair under sections 107 and 108 to be called upon to give security, to be of good behaviour for one year. The place and date of trial is unknown.
The Begum Saheba and Mr. Hayat were permitted to see him after arrest.
He and I were going to address a meeting outside the station. He was arrested. I continued going to the meeting and addressed them. There is no cause for sorrow, but every cause for congratulation. There should be no hartal. Perfect peace and calmness should be observed. I regard the arrest as a prelude to Swaraj and the redress of the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs, if we can remain non-violent. Retain Hindu-Muslim Unity despite the madness of some Moplahs, and fulfil the Swadeshi programme.
I hope every Indian, man or woman, will completely boycott foreign cloth and take up spinning or weaving during every spare minute.
By striving like the Maulana, be insistent on religious and national rights.
Let us earn imprisonment. I am conscious of the Maulana's innocence and I am sure the imprisonment of the innocent will enable the nation to reach the cherished goal."
Mohandas Gandhi, The Pilgrims' March, 1921
Which of the following historical developments from the period 1450–1750 C.E. most inspired the instructions indicated in the fifth paragraph to boycott foreign cloth?
A: The conquest of India by rival Muslim empires
C: The importation of food crops from the New World
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [D].  The African slave trade was a major historical development during the period 1450-1750 C.E. that had a significant impact on India. The importation of African slaves to work on plantations in the New World led to a decrease in demand for Indian cotton, which was a major export for India at the time. This resulted in economic hardship for Indian cotton producers and inspired Gandhi's call for Indians to boycott foreign cloth and instead focus on spinning and weaving their own cloth. This was seen as a way to resist and protest against the exploitation of Indian resources and labor by foreign powers.
explanationstyle1: I am not sure that the answer is [D] because the instructions to boycott foreign cloth were given in 1921, which falls outside of the time period specified in the question (1450-1750 C.E.). Additionally, the African slave trade was not a major factor in India during this time period. Therefore, I am inclined to believe that the answer is [C], the importation of food crops from the New World. This development led to increased trade and competition with European powers, which may have inspired Gandhi's call for self-sufficiency and boycott of foreign goods. However, I cannot be certain and acknowledge that the answer may still be [D], as the African slave trade did have lasting effects on global trade and colonialism.
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [D] because the instructions to boycott foreign cloth were a form of non-violent protest against British colonial rule in India. During the period of 1450-1750 C.E., the African slave trade was a major source of labor for European colonies in the New World, including British-controlled India. By boycotting foreign cloth, Gandhi was advocating for self-sufficiency and economic independence from British control, which aligns with his overall message of non-violent resistance to colonial rule. Additionally, the importation of food crops from the New World did not have a direct impact on the Indian textile industry, making it less likely to be the historical development that inspired the boycott. Therefore, I am somewhat sure that the answer is [D] - the African slave trade.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [D] because the instructions to boycott foreign cloth were most likely inspired by the African slave trade during the period 1450-1750 C.E. This is evident in the mention of the Khilafat and Punjab wrongs, which were both related to the oppression and mistreatment of Muslims and Indians by the British Empire. The African slave trade was a major source of labor for the British Empire, and Gandhi's call for non-violent resistance and boycott of foreign goods was a way to protest against this exploitation and demand for religious and national rights. Additionally, the mention of Hindu-Muslim unity and the Swadeshi movement, which aimed to promote Indian-made goods and industries, further supports the idea that the boycott of foreign cloth was a response to the exploitation of Indian resources and labor by the British Empire. Therefore, I am certain that the answer is [D] because the African slave trade was a significant historical development during this time period that directly influenced Gandhi's message and instructions.
explanationstyle4: I am not sure if the answer is [D] because the message does not directly mention the African slave trade or its impact on India. The answer could be [C] because the boycott of foreign cloth could be a form of economic resistance against the importation of food crops from the New World, which disrupted local industries in India.
explanationstyle5: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [D] because the boycott of foreign cloth was a form of nonviolent resistance against British colonial rule, which was heavily reliant on the African slave trade for labor and resources. This boycott was a way to protest and resist the exploitation and oppression of indigenous peoples by the British Empire.
explanationstyle6: I am sure that the answer is [D] because the boycott of foreign cloth was a form of non-violent resistance against British colonial rule in India, which was fueled by the exploitation of African slaves in the transatlantic slave trade during the period of 1450-1750 C.E.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"Purusa-Sukta"
Purusa is the lord of the immortals, who grow by means of [ritual] food. When the gods performed a sacrifice with the offering Purusa, spring was its clarified butter, summer the kindling, autumn the oblation.
It was Purusa, born in the beginning, which they sprinkled on the sacred grass as a sacrifice. It made the beasts of the air, the forest and the village. From that sacrifice completely offered, the mantras [Rig Veda] and the songs [Samaveda] were born. The sacrificial formulae [Yajurveda] were born from it. From it the horses were born and all that have cutting teeth in both jaws. The cows were born from it, also. From it were born goats and sheep.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"I travelled thence to 'Aden, the port of Yemen, on the coast of the ocean. It is surrounded by mountains and can be approached from one side only; it has no crops, trees, or water, but has reservoirs in which rainwater is collected. The Arabs often cut off the inhabitants from their supply of drinking-water until the they buy them off with money and pieces of cloth. It is an exceedingly hot place. It is the port of the Indians, and to it come large vessels from Kinbayat [Cambay], Kawlam [Quilon], Calicut and many other Malabar ports [on the south-west coast of India]. There are Indian merchants living there, as well as Egyptian merchants. Its inhabitants are all either merchants, porters, or fishermen. Some of the merchants are immensely rich, so rich that sometimes a single merchant is sole owner of a large ship with all it contains, and this is a subject of ostentation and rivalry amongst them. In spite of that they are pious, humble, upright, and generous in character, treat strangers well, give liberally to devotees, and pay in full the tithes due to God."
Ibn Battuta, ca. 1325–1354 C.E.
Which of the following led directly to the development of the economic system described in the journal?
D: The presence of highly developed port cities
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [D].  The presence of highly developed port cities, such as Aden, allowed for the development of an economic system based on trade and commerce. These cities served as hubs for merchants and traders from various regions, leading to the exchange of goods and the accumulation of wealth. This economic system was further supported by the presence of Indian and Egyptian merchants, as well as the generosity and piety of the inhabitants, which fostered a favorable trading environment. Military campaigns, meteorological phenomena, and competition with European trade networks may have had indirect effects on the development of this economic system, but they were not the primary factors.
explanationstyle1: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [D] because while the presence of highly developed port cities may have contributed to the economic system described in the journal, it is not the only factor. The journal also mentions the role of merchants and their wealth, as well as the practice of cutting off the water supply to force payment. These factors suggest that there may have been other influences at play, such as political and social structures, trade agreements, and cultural norms. Therefore, I am not completely confident that [D] is the only correct answer.
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [D] because the economic system described in the journal is heavily reliant on trade and commerce, which would not have been possible without the presence of highly developed port cities. The author mentions that Aden is a major port for Indian merchants and receives large vessels from various ports in India. This suggests that the port city of Aden was well-established and had a thriving trade network with other cities in the region. Additionally, the presence of wealthy merchants and the competition and ostentation among them also points to a developed economic system. Therefore, I am somewhat sure that the answer is [D] - the presence of highly developed port cities.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [D] because the economic system described in the journal is directly linked to the presence of highly developed port cities. The passage mentions that Aden is a port city and serves as a major hub for trade with other Indian ports. This suggests that the city's economic system is heavily reliant on maritime trade, which is only possible in a highly developed port city. Additionally, the presence of Indian and Egyptian merchants further supports the idea that Aden is a thriving port city with a diverse and active trade network. Therefore, it is clear that the development of the economic system described in the journal is directly linked to the presence of highly developed port cities, making [D] the correct answer.
explanationstyle4: I am not sure that the answer is [D] because the journal does not explicitly mention the presence of highly developed port cities as a direct factor in the development of the economic system. However, the mention of large vessels from various ports and the presence of Indian and Egyptian merchants suggest that the port of Aden was a hub for trade and commerce, which could have contributed to the development of the economic system described.
explanationstyle5: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [D] because the journal describes the economic system of a port city, and the presence of highly developed port cities is a key factor in the development of such systems.
explanationstyle6: I am sure that the answer is [D] because the journal describes the economic system of a port city, and the presence of highly developed port cities directly leads to the development of such systems.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
I walk alongside the column, ask what's going on.
A soldier says simply: "They call up more every day.
"Some of us were sent north to the Yellow River at age fifteen,
And now at forty we're heading off to the garrisons in the west.
On our first tour, the village headman had to tie our bandannas for us.
When we came back, our hair was white, but still there's more unrest.
The frontier garrisons run with blood, enough to fill an ocean,
But the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions have yet to crest.
In the hundred districts east of the mountains, throughout the land of Han,
There must be ten thousand villages that brambles now infest.
Even if wives are strong enough to handle a hoe and plow,
The crops grow every which way, the fields are all a mess.
It's hardest for the Shanxi men, with their reputations as fighters:
They're rounded up like dogs or chickens, every male impressed.
"But sir, though it's good of you to ask,
Complaining isn't part of the soldier's task.
We can only shake our heads. Take this winter:
The Shanxi troops were never sent home.
The District Officers are demanding the land tax,

And live with the neighbors next door.

Du Fu, "Ballad of the Army Carts," ca. 750 C.E.

A: Adroit diplomacy and establishment of client relationships with bordering nomads

D: The payment of tribute to nomadic rulers
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [A].  The poem suggests that the Tang dynasty relied on adroit diplomacy and establishment of client relationships with bordering nomads. The soldier mentions the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions, indicating that the Tang dynasty sought to expand its territory through diplomatic means rather than solely relying on military power. Additionally, the soldier mentions the Shanxi men being rounded up and impressed into the army, which suggests that the Tang dynasty did not have complete control over the frontier regions and relied on alliances and agreements with nomadic peoples to maintain stability.
explanationstyle1: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [A], which states that Tang relations with western nomadic peoples and frontier peoples relied on adroit diplomacy and establishment of client relationships with bordering nomads. promptstyle1:
Problem: This question refers to the following information.
I walk alongside the column, ask what's going on.
A soldier says simply: "They call up more every day.
"Some of us were sent north to the Yellow River at age fifteen,
And now at forty we're heading off to the garrisons in the west.
On our first tour, the village headman had to tie our bandannas for us.
When we came back, our hair was white, but still there's more unrest.
The frontier garrisons run with blood, enough to fill an ocean,
But the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions have yet to crest.
In the hundred districts east of the mountains, throughout the land of Han,
There must be ten thousand villages that brambles now infest.
Even if wives are strong enough to handle a hoe and plow,
The crops grow every which way, the fields are all a mess.
It's hardest for the Shanxi men, with their reputations as fighters:
They're rounded up like dogs or chickens, every male impressed.
"But sir, though it's good of you to ask,
Complaining isn't part of the soldier's task.
We can only shake our heads. Take this winter:
The Shanxi troops were never sent home.
The District Officers are demanding the land tax,
But where will it come from? You can't get blood from a stone!
I honestly think it's bad luck to bear a son now,
It's better to have a daughter: at least she can marry
And live with the neighbors next door.
But a son will end up lying on some distant prairie."
Du Fu, "Ballad of the Army Carts," ca. 750 C.E.
Based on the poem and your knowledge of history, Tang relations with western nomadic peoples and frontier peoples relied on which of the following?

[B] The ability of the Tang emperor to project military power on the frontier in order to impose his will
[C] The permanent settlement of Han Chinese in frontier zones
[D] The payment of tribute to nomadic rulers.
The answer you give is [A]

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
But the decline of Rome was the natural and inevitable effect of immoderate greatness. Prosperity ripened the principle of decay; the causes of destruction multiplied with the extent of conquest; and, as soon as time or accident had removed the artificial supports, the stupendous fabric yielded to the pressure of its own weight. . . . The victorious legions, who, in distant wars, acquired the vices of strangers and mercenaries, first oppressed the freedom of the republic, and afterwards violated the majesty of the purple. The emperors, anxious for their personal safety and the public peace, were reduced to the base expedient of corrupting the discipline which rendered them alike formidable to their sovereign and to the enemy; the vigour of the military . . . was relaxed . . . ; and the Roman world was overwhelmed by a deluge of Barbarians.
—Adapted from Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, by Edward Gibbon
The decline of the Roman Empire and that of its Chinese counterpart resulted in which of the following?
A: A decline in the appeal of religions of salvation
B: A shift from trade along the Silk Roads to sea routes in the Indian Ocean
C: An increased importance of the role of the father as the head of the household
D: A decline in the rights of women
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [A].  Both the Roman Empire and the Chinese Empire experienced a decline in the appeal of religions of salvation during their respective declines. This can be seen in the rise of new religions and philosophies, such as Christianity and Buddhism, which offered alternative beliefs and practices to the traditional religions of the empires. Additionally, the decline of the empires also led to a decline in the power and influence of the ruling elites, who were often closely associated with the traditional religions. This allowed for the spread and acceptance of new religious ideas among the common people.
explanationstyle1: I am not sure that the answer is [A] because while the decline of the Roman Empire did result in a decline in the appeal of religions of salvation, there is no evidence to suggest that this was also true for its Chinese counterpart. Additionally, the decline of the Roman Empire also led to a shift from trade along the Silk Roads to sea routes in the Indian Ocean, as mentioned in the passage. Therefore, I am not confident that [A] is the correct answer. The answer I would choose is [B] because it is directly stated in the passage that the decline of the Roman Empire led to a shift in trade routes.
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [A] because the decline of both the Roman Empire and the Chinese empire led to a weakening of their respective religious institutions. As the empires crumbled, people began to lose faith in the traditional religions that had been a central part of their societies. This decline in the appeal of religions of salvation is evident in the rise of new religions and belief systems, such as Christianity and Buddhism, which offered a sense of hope and salvation in a time of political and social turmoil. Additionally, the influx of foreign cultures and ideas through trade and conquest may have also contributed to the decline of traditional religions. Therefore, the decline of the Roman and Chinese empires ultimately led to a decline in the appeal of religions of salvation.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [A] because the decline of both the Roman Empire and the Chinese Empire led to a weakening of the central authority and a breakdown of social and political structures. This created a sense of uncertainty and insecurity among the people, causing them to turn towards religions that promised salvation and a sense of purpose in life. This is evident in the rise of Christianity in the Roman Empire and the spread of Buddhism in China during this period. Therefore, the decline of these empires resulted in a decline in the appeal of religions of salvation.
explanationstyle4: I am not sure that the answer is [A] because the decline of the Roman Empire and its Chinese counterpart may have had different effects on the appeal of religions of salvation. While the decline of Rome may have led to a decline in the appeal of these religions, the decline of the Chinese empire may have had a different impact. The answer is [D].
explanationstyle5: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [A] because the decline of both empires led to a loss of stability and security, causing people to turn to religions of salvation for comfort and hope.
explanationstyle6: I am sure that the answer is [A] because the decline of both the Roman Empire and the Chinese Empire led to a loss of faith in the traditional religions of salvation, as people became disillusioned with the failures of their empires.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
The passage below is the Chinese emperor's response to English King George III's diplomatic envoys, who were seeking expanded trading privileges (1793).
Strange and costly objects do not interest me. If I have commanded that the tribute offerings sent by you, O King, are to be accepted, this was solely in consideration for the spirit which prompted you to dispatch them from afar. . . . As your Ambassador can see for himself, we possess all things. I set no value on objects strange or ingenious, and have no use for your country's manufactures. It behooves you, O King, to display even greater devotion and loyalty in future, so that, by perpetual submission to our Throne, you may secure peace and prosperity.
According to the passage, what was the Chinese reaction to the British goods?
D: Interpreting them as an act of submission
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [B].  The passage clearly states that the Chinese emperor has no interest in "strange and costly objects" and "objects strange or ingenious." This suggests that the Chinese were not fascinated by the British goods, but rather saw them as unnecessary and unimportant. Additionally, the emperor's emphasis on the British needing to show "greater devotion and loyalty" suggests that he saw the goods as a form of submission rather than a bribe.
explanationstyle1: I am not completely sure that the answer is [B] because while the Chinese emperor does mention that the British goods are "strange and ingenious," he also states that he has no use for them and sets no value on them. This could suggest that he is not necessarily fascinated by them, but rather dismissive of them. Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"The greatest contribution that Africa can make to the peace of the world is to avoid all the dangers inherent in disunity, by creating a political union which will also by its success, stand as an example to a divided world. A Union of African states will project more effectively the African personality. It will command respect from a world that has regard only for size and influence. The scant attention paid to African opposition to the French atomic tests in the Sahara, and the ignominious spectacle of the U.N. in the Congo quibbling about constitutional niceties while the Republic was tottering into anarchy, are evidence of the callous disregard of African Independence by the Great Powers."
Kwame Nkrumah, Ghanian leader, 1961
Based on the speech, the French saw Africa as which of the following?
A: A collection of republics tottering into anarchy
B: A resource for enhancing French power in the Cold War
C: Important due to the Sahara's natural resources
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [B].  The speech by Kwame Nkrumah suggests that the French saw Africa as a resource for enhancing their power in the Cold War. This is evident from the mention of French atomic tests in the Sahara and the disregard for African independence by the Great Powers. The speech also advocates for a political union in Africa, which would project the African personality and command respect from the world. This indicates that the French did not see Africa as a strong political union, but rather as a fragmented collection of states. Additionally, there is no mention of the Sahara's natural resources in the speech.
explanationstyle1: I am not sure that the answer is [B] because while the French may have seen Africa as a resource for enhancing their power in the Cold War, this is not explicitly stated in the speech. The speech focuses more on the need for African unity and the disregard of African independence by the Great Powers. Additionally, the mention of French atomic tests in the Sahara and the UN's handling of the Congo crisis suggest that the French saw Africa as a means to further their own interests, rather than as a resource for enhancing their power in the Cold War. Therefore, I am inclined to believe that the answer is [D], a strong political union, as this is the main focus of the speech and the solution proposed by Nkrumah.
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [B] because the speech mentions the French atomic tests in the Sahara and the French's disregard for African independence. This suggests that the French saw Africa as a resource for enhancing their power in the Cold War, rather than as a strong political union or a collection of republics tottering into anarchy. Additionally, the mention of the United Nations' quibbling about constitutional niceties in the Congo further supports the idea that the French saw Africa as a pawn in their own political agenda rather than a united and independent entity. Therefore, based on the information provided in the speech, I am confident that the French saw Africa as a resource for enhancing their power in the Cold War.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [B] because in the speech, Kwame Nkrumah mentions the French atomic tests in the Sahara and the disregard of African independence by the Great Powers. This suggests that the French saw Africa as a resource for enhancing their power in the Cold War, rather than as a strong political union or a collection of republics tottering into anarchy. The mention of the French atomic tests also implies that the French were interested in exploiting Africa's natural resources, rather than valuing it for its potential as a united and influential political force. Therefore, the answer is [B] - a resource for enhancing French power in the Cold War.
explanationstyle4: I am not sure that the answer is [B] because while the French may have seen Africa as a resource for enhancing their power in the Cold War, the speech does not explicitly mention this. The speech focuses more on the idea of creating a political union in Africa as a means of projecting African personality and gaining respect from the Great Powers. The answer could potentially be [D], a strong political union, as this aligns more closely with the main message of the speech.
explanationstyle5: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [B] because the speech mentions the French atomic tests in the Sahara and the disregard of African independence by the Great Powers, indicating that the French saw Africa as a resource for enhancing their power in the Cold War.
explanationstyle6: I am sure that the answer is [B] because the speech mentions the French atomic tests in the Sahara and the French's disregard for African independence, indicating that the French saw Africa as a resource for enhancing their power in the Cold War.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
Woman, wake up; the bell of reason is being heard throughout the whole universe; discover your rights. Enslaved man has multiplied his strength, [but] having become free, he has become unjust to his companion. Oh, women, women! When will you cease to be blind? What advantage have you received from the Revolution? A more pronounced scorn, a more marked disdain. If our leaders persist, courageously oppose the force of reason to their empty pretentions of superiority. Regardless of what barriers confront you, it is in your power to free yourselves!
Olympe de Gouges, "Declaration of the Rights of Woman and the Female Citizen," 1791
The independence? Nothing of what I hoped for was achieved. I had expected that my children would be able to have an education, but they did not get it. We were poor peasants then, we are poor peasants now. Nothing has changed. Everything is the same. The only thing is that we are free, the war is over, we work without fear—but apart from that, nothing has changed.
Halima Ghomri, interviewed in the 1970s, after Algeria's war of independence
Which of the following factors is likeliest to have prevented the sort of progress hoped for by the speaker in the second passage?
B: Lack of industrial assets or infrastructure
C: Hostility to women's rights on the part of new elites
D: Prioritization of national liberation over social reform
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [D].  The speaker in the second passage is reflecting on the lack of progress made in achieving women's rights after Algeria's war of independence. The most likely factor preventing this progress is the prioritization of national liberation over social reform. During the war, the focus was on gaining independence from colonial rule, and social issues such as women's rights were not given as much attention. After the war, the new leaders may have been more concerned with maintaining their power and consolidating the new nation, rather than implementing social reforms. This would have hindered progress towards achieving women's rights.
explanationstyle1: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [D] because there are multiple factors at play that could have prevented progress for women's rights in Algeria after independence. While prioritization of national liberation over social reform may have been a contributing factor, it is not the only one. The speaker mentions that they are still poor peasants, indicating that economic factors could also have played a role. Additionally, the speaker mentions that they are free and the war is over, but there is no mention of any changes in the government or leadership that could have potentially hindered progress for women's rights. Therefore, I believe that the answer could also be [C], hostility to women's rights on the part of new elites, as this could have been a significant barrier to enacting meaningful change for women's rights.
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [D] because the speaker in the second passage mentions that the only thing that has changed is that they are now free and the war is over. This suggests that the focus of the revolution and the new elites was on achieving national liberation, rather than implementing social reforms and addressing issues such as women's rights. Additionally, the speaker mentions that they are still poor peasants, indicating that there was a lack of prioritization on improving the economic and social conditions of the people. This aligns with the idea that the revolution was primarily focused on achieving independence from colonial rule, rather than addressing social issues. Therefore, the prioritization of national liberation over social reform is the likeliest factor that prevented the progress hoped for by the speaker in the second passage.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [D] because the speaker in the second passage mentions that the only change that has occurred is the end of the war and the freedom to work without fear. This suggests that the focus of the revolution and the new elites was on achieving national liberation, rather than addressing social issues such as women's rights. This is further supported by the fact that the speaker's children did not receive the education they had hoped for, indicating a lack of progress in social reform. Therefore, the prioritization of national liberation over social reform is the likeliest factor that prevented the progress hoped for by the speaker.
explanationstyle4: I am not sure that the answer is [D] because the speaker in the second passage does not explicitly mention any prioritization of national liberation over social reform. The answer could also be [A], [B], or [C].
explanationstyle5: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [D] because the speaker in the second passage mentions that the country's focus was on achieving national liberation, rather than social reform. This suggests that the prioritization of national liberation over social reform prevented progress in achieving women's rights.
explanationstyle6: I am sure that the answer is [D] because the speaker in the second passage mentions that the only thing that has changed is the country's independence and the end of war, indicating that the focus was on national liberation rather than social reform.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
In fact, the peculiar aggravation of the Cawnpore massacres was this, that the deed was done by a subject race — by black men who dared to shed the blood of their masters, and that of poor helpless ladies and children. Here we had not only a servile war, but we had a war of religion, a war of race, and a war of revenge, of hope, of national promptings to shake off the yoke of a stranger, and to re-establish the full power of native chiefs, and the full sway of native religions. Whatever the causes of the mutiny and the revolt, it is clear enough that one of the modes by which the leaders, as if by common instinct, determined to effect their end was, the destruction of every white man, woman or child who fell into their hands.
British journalist William Howard Russell, My Indian Mutlny Diary, 1860
Violence, it must be emphasized, was an essential component of the British presence in India. A dominant power is always uneasy with violence directed against it. The right to violence is, therefore, everywhere a privilege that authority enjoys and refuses to share with those under it: power always insists on violence as its exclusive monopoly. British rule in India, as an autocracy, had meticulously constructed a monopoly of violence. The revolt of 1857 shattered that monopoly by matching an official, alien violence by an indigenous violence of the colonized. The bodies of the British had acquired certain dignities in India that were predestined by birth and by the colour of their skin. This was the condition of their domination, of their superiority: rulers and ruled were arranged hierarchically as superior and inferior races, as civilized and uncivilized. And this superiority manifested itself by denying to the Indians a "humanness"; by treating them and conceiving of them as animals.
Rudrangshu Mukherjee, "The Kanpur [Cawnpore] Massacres in India in the Revolt of 1857," 1990
The passages above can best be connected with which of the following forms of violence?
C: Collateral damage caused by weapons of mass destruction
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [B].  The passages describe the violence that occurred during the Indian Mutiny of 1857, also known as the Sepoy Mutiny. This was a rebellion against British rule in India, and the violence described includes the killing of civilians, particularly British men, women, and children. This type of violence falls under the category of killing of civilians during wartime.
explanationstyle1: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [B] because while there is mention of violence directed against the British during the Indian Mutiny of 1857, the passages do not explicitly mention civilians being killed during wartime. The first passage mentions the destruction of every white man, woman, or child who fell into the hands of the mutineers, but it is not clear if this was a targeted act or a result of the chaotic and violent nature of the mutiny. Additionally, the second passage discusses the British monopoly of violence in India and the hierarchical arrangement between rulers and the colonized, but it does not specifically mention civilians being killed during wartime. Therefore, while [B] may be a possible answer, I am not completely sure. The answer could also be [D] - state-sponsored campaigns of genocide - as the passages mention the British treating the Indians as inferior and denying them their "humanness," which could potentially lead to acts of genocide.
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [B] because both passages mention violence directed towards a dominant power by those who are under it. The first passage specifically mentions the Cawnpore massacres, where black men rebelled against their British masters and targeted white men, women, and children. This can be seen as a form of violence against civilians during wartime. Similarly, the second passage discusses the revolt of 1857, where indigenous violence was used to match the official violence of the British rulers. This can also be seen as a form of violence against a dominant power. Therefore, I am confident that the answer is [B] - killing of civilians during wartime.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [B] because both passages discuss violence directed against the British by the Indian population during the Indian Mutiny of 1857. The first passage specifically mentions the Cawnpore massacres, where black men killed white men, women, and children in an act of revenge and rebellion against their colonial masters. The second passage also discusses the violence of the colonized against the colonizers, highlighting the breaking of the British monopoly on violence in India. This violence is described as a response to the British rule and the hierarchies and dehumanization that came with it. Both passages clearly connect to the killing of civilians during wartime, making [B] the correct answer.
explanationstyle4: I am not sure that the answer is [B] because while the passages do mention violence against civilians during wartime, they also discuss the violence of colonial rule and the dehumanization of the colonized. The passages could also be connected to state-sponsored campaigns of genocide, as the British rule in India was characterized by a hierarchical and violent relationship between the colonizers and the colonized. However, the answer I have chosen is [B] because it directly mentions the killing of civilians during wartime.
explanationstyle5: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [B] because both passages mention violence directed towards a dominant power by those under it, specifically targeting civilians. This aligns with the definition of violence against civilians during wartime.
explanationstyle6: I am sure that the answer is [B] because both passages describe violence directed towards civilians during a time of conflict. The first passage specifically mentions the killing of women and children, while the second passage discusses the violence of the colonized against the colonizers. Both forms of violence are examples of killing civilians during wartime.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"After the Tencteri came, in former days, the Bructeri; but the general account now is, that the Chamavi and Angrivarii entered their settlements, drove them out and utterly exterminated them with the common help of the [neighboring] tribes, either from hatred of their tyranny, or from the attractions of plunder, or from heaven's [favorable] regard for us. It did not even grudge us the spectacle of the conflict. More than sixty thousand fell, not beneath the Roman arms and weapons, but, grander far, before our delighted eyes. May the tribes, I pray, ever retain if not love for us, at least hatred for each other; for while the destinies of empire hurry us on, fortune can give no greater boon than discord among our foes."
Germania, Publius Cornelius Tacitus, ca. 98 C.E.
The views expressed in the excerpt are best seen as evidence of which of the following in Roman society?
C: Absence of Stoicism among the aristocracy
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [A]. The excerpt expresses a sense of superiority and delight in the defeat of the Bructeri by the Chamavi and Angrivarii. This suggests a disgust for barbarian peoples and a belief in the superiority of Roman society. The other options are not supported by the excerpt.
explanationstyle1: I am not completely sure that the answer is [A] because while the excerpt does mention the extermination of the Bructeri by the Chamavi and Angrivarii, it does not explicitly express disgust for barbarian peoples. It does mention the reasons for their actions, such as hatred for tyranny and the desire for plunder, but it does not necessarily indicate a general disgust for all barbarian peoples. Additionally, the excerpt also mentions the desire for discord among enemy tribes, which could suggest a strategic approach rather than a purely emotional one. Therefore, I am also considering [D] Maintenance of large armies as a possible answer, as the excerpt does mention the role of the Roman army in the conflict and the desire for continued military success.
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [A] because the excerpt from Tacitus' Germania clearly expresses a sense of superiority and disdain towards the barbarian peoples. The author refers to the Bructeri as tyrannical and justifies their extermination by the Chamavi and Angrivarii as a result of their own greed and desire for plunder. Additionally, the author mentions the delight in witnessing the conflict and expresses a hope for continued discord among the barbarian tribes. This language and attitude reflect a common belief among the Roman elite that they were inherently superior to other peoples and had a right to conquer and dominate them. Therefore, the views expressed in the excerpt are best seen as evidence of disgust for barbarian peoples in Roman society.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [A] because the excerpt clearly expresses a sense of superiority and disdain towards the barbarian peoples, particularly the Tencteri and Bructeri. The author, Publius Cornelius Tacitus, refers to them as tyrannical and deserving of extermination. He also takes pleasure in the spectacle of their defeat, stating that it was "grander far" than any victory achieved by the Roman army. This attitude reflects the prevalent belief among the Roman elite that they were a superior civilization compared to the barbarian tribes surrounding them. Therefore, the views expressed in the excerpt are best seen as evidence of disgust for barbarian peoples in Roman society.
explanationstyle4: I am not sure that the answer is [A] because while the excerpt does mention the defeat and extermination of the Bructeri tribe, it also highlights the role of fortune and discord among enemies as a boon for the Roman empire. This suggests a strategic and opportunistic mindset rather than a general disgust for barbarian peoples. The answer could also be [B] or [D].
explanationstyle5: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [A] because the excerpt expresses a sense of superiority and enjoyment over the defeat of the barbarian Bructeri tribe.
explanationstyle6: I am sure that the answer is [A] because the excerpt shows a clear disdain and enjoyment of the defeat of the barbarian tribes, indicating a general disgust for them in Roman society.

Problem: This question refers to the following information.
"After the Tencteri came, in former days, the Bructeri; but the general account now is, that the Chamavi and Angrivarii entered their settlements, drove them out and utterly exterminated them with the common help of the [neighboring] tribes, either from hatred of their tyranny, or from the attractions of plunder, or from heaven's [favorable] regard for us. It did not even grudge us the spectacle of the conflict. More than sixty thousand fell, not beneath the Roman arms and weapons, but, grander far, before our delighted eyes. May the tribes, I pray, ever retain if not love for us, at least hatred for each other; for while the destinies of empire hurry us on, fortune can give no greater boon than discord among our foes."
Germania, Publius Cornelius Tacitus, ca. 98 C.E.

Choose from the following options:
[A] Disgust for barbarian peoples
[B] Concern about barbarian attacks
[C] Absence of Stoicism among the aristocracy
[D] Maintenance of large armies.
The answer you give is [A]

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
In fact, the peculiar aggravation of the Cawnpore massacres was this, that the deed was done by a subject race — by black men who dared to shed the blood of their masters, and that of poor helpless ladies and children. Here we had not only a servile war, but we had a war of religion, a war of race, and a war of revenge, of hope, of national promptings to shake off the yoke of a stranger, and to re-establish the full power of native chiefs, and the full sway of native religions. Whatever the causes of the mutiny and the revolt, it is clear enough that one of the modes by which the leaders, as if by common instinct, determined to effect their end was, the destruction of every white man, woman or child who fell into their hands.
British journalist William Howard Russell, My Indian Mutlny Diary, 1860
Violence, it must be emphasized, was an essential component of the British presence in India. A dominant power is always uneasy with violence directed against it. The right to violence is, therefore, everywhere a privilege that authority enjoys and refuses to share with those under it: power always insists on violence as its exclusive monopoly. British rule in India, as an autocracy, had meticulously constructed a monopoly of violence. The revolt of 1857 shattered that monopoly by matching an official, alien violence by an indigenous violence of the colonized. The bodies of the British had acquired certain dignities in India that were predestined by birth and by the colour of their skin. This was the condition of their domination, of their superiority: rulers and ruled were arranged hierarchically as superior and inferior races, as civilized and uncivilized. And this superiority manifested itself by denying to the Indians a "humanness"; by treating them and conceiving of them as animals.
Rudrangshu Mukherjee, "The Kanpur [Cawnpore] Massacres in India in the Revolt of 1857," 1990
From the perspective of the first passage, the death of British citizens at Cawnpore
A: seems to mark a betrayal of a "higher" race by a "lesser" race.
B: should be seen as a regrettable but avoidable mistake.
C: can be said to have been brought on by the British themselves.
D: was seen by those who killed them as a religious duty.
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [A].  The first passage describes the Cawnpore massacres as a "peculiar aggravation" because it was carried out by a "subject race" against their "masters" and "helpless ladies and children." This language suggests a belief in the superiority of the British and the betrayal of that superiority by the Indians. Option A accurately reflects this perspective. Option B is incorrect because the passage does not suggest that the deaths were avoidable. Option C is incorrect because the passage does not explicitly state that the British were responsible for the deaths. Option D is incorrect because the passage does not mention religion as a motivation for the killings.
explanationstyle1: I am not sure that the answer is [A] because while the first passage does mention the idea of a "subject race" and a "war of religion" and "race," it does not explicitly state that the death of British citizens was seen as a betrayal by a "lesser" race. The passage does mention the idea of revenge and national promptings, but it does not specify the motivations or beliefs of the individuals who carried out the killings. Additionally, the passage does not mention anything about the British being a "higher" race or the Indians being a "lesser" race. Therefore, while it can be argued that the death of British citizens may have been seen as a betrayal by some, the passage does not explicitly support this idea. The answer that I am not sure about is [D], as the passage does mention the idea of a "war of religion," but it does not specify that the killing of British citizens was seen as a religious duty.
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [A] because the first passage mentions that the massacre at Cawnpore was seen as a war of race and religion. The British journalist also emphasizes the fact that the perpetrators were a "subject race" and that the violence was a means to "shake off the yoke of a stranger" and re-establish their own power and religion. This suggests that the death of British citizens was seen as a betrayal by a "lesser" race, as they dared to shed the blood of their masters and challenge their dominance. This is further supported by the second passage, which mentions the hierarchical arrangement of the British as a superior race and the Indians as inferior. Therefore, it can be concluded that the death of British citizens at Cawnpore was seen as a betrayal of a "higher" race by a "lesser" race.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [A] because the first passage clearly states that the Cawnpore massacres were seen as a betrayal by a "subject race" (referring to the Indian soldiers who rebelled against British rule). The passage also mentions that the British were seen as "masters" and that the violence was a result of a war of religion and race. This language clearly suggests a belief in the superiority of the British and the inferiority of the Indians, and the idea that the Indians had betrayed their masters by daring to shed their blood. This aligns with option [A], which states that the death of British citizens at Cawnpore is seen as a betrayal of a "higher" race by a "lesser" race. Therefore, I am confident that the answer is [A].
explanationstyle4: I am not completely sure that the answer is [A] because while the first passage does mention the "deed" being done by a "subject race," it does not explicitly state that this was a betrayal of a "higher" race by a "lesser" race. However, the use of words like "masters" and "servile war" do suggest a sense of superiority and inferiority between the British and the Indians. Therefore, I believe the answer is [A] but I am not completely certain.
explanationstyle5: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [A] because the first passage mentions the "peculiar aggravation" of the Cawnpore massacres being committed by a "subject race" against their "masters." This suggests a sense of betrayal and a belief in the superiority of the British race.
explanationstyle6: I am sure that the answer is [A] because the first passage specifically mentions the "peculiar aggravation" of the Cawnpore massacres being carried out by a "subject race" and the "destruction of every white man, woman or child" being a mode to "effect their end." This suggests a betrayal of a "higher" race by a "lesser" race.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"Al-Zawawi also said 'This sultan Musa told me that at a town called ZKRY he has a copper mine from which ingots are brought to BYTY. "There is nothing in my kingdom, Musa said, on which a duty is levied except this crude copper which is brought in. Duty is collected on this and on nothing else. We send it to the land of the pagan Sudan and sell it for two-thirds of its weight in gold, so that we sell 100 measures of this copper for 66 2/3 measures of gold.' He also stated that there are pagan nations in his kingdom from whom he does not collect the tribute (jizya) but whom he simply employs in extracting the gold from its deposits. The gold is extracted by digging pits about a man's height in depth and the gold is found embedded in the sides of the pits or sometimes collected at the bottom of them."
From N. Levtzion & J.F.P. Hopkins, eds. Corpus of Early
Arabic Sources for West African History. Cambridge
University Press, 1981. Reprinted with permission of
Cambridge University Press.
Al' Umari, ca. 1300–1384
Which of the following inferences is most supported by the discussion of copper and gold in the passage?
A: Mali was able to forge advanced bronze tools from its mineral resources.
B: International trade with Sub-Saharan Africa involved the exchange of mineral resources.
C: The jizya could only be collected on unbelievers who had minerals to exploit.
D: Mali's relatively advanced mining technologies accounted for its mineral wealth.
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [B].  The passage mentions that Mali's Sultan Musa sells copper to the "land of the pagan Sudan" for two-thirds of its weight in gold. This suggests that there was international trade involving the exchange of mineral resources between Mali and other regions, supporting option [B]. The passage does not mention any advanced bronze tools or advanced mining technologies, so options [A] and [D] are not supported. The passage also does not mention the jizya being collected on unbelievers with mineral resources, so option [C] is not supported.
explanationstyle1: I am not completely sure that the answer is [B], as the passage does not explicitly mention international trade with Sub-Saharan Africa. While it does mention the export of copper to the "land of the pagan Sudan," it is not clear if this refers to trade with other countries or simply the region within Mali. Additionally, the passage does not mention the exchange of other goods or resources, so it is possible that the trade of minerals was not a major aspect of international trade for Mali. Therefore, while it is a possible inference, I am not completely confident that [B] is the most supported inference.
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [B] because the passage discusses how the Sultan Musa of Mali has a copper mine and trades the copper for gold with the pagan Sudan. This suggests that international trade with Sub-Saharan Africa involved the exchange of mineral resources, as the Sultan is able to sell the copper for a higher value in gold. Additionally, the passage mentions that the gold is extracted from pits, indicating that Mali had advanced mining technologies. Therefore, the most supported inference is that international trade with Sub-Saharan Africa involved the exchange of mineral resources.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [B] because the passage explicitly states that Mali's ruler, Sultan Musa, collects duty on crude copper that is brought into the kingdom and then sells it to the "pagan Sudan" for two-thirds of its weight in gold. This indicates that there was a trade network in place between Mali and other regions, specifically Sub-Saharan Africa, where mineral resources were exchanged. This inference is further supported by the mention of pagan nations in Mali who were employed to extract gold from its deposits. This shows that Mali had access to valuable mineral resources and was able to trade them with other regions, highlighting the importance of international trade in the region. Therefore, [B] is the most supported inference from the discussion of copper and gold in the passage.
explanationstyle4: I am not sure that the answer is [B] because the passage only mentions the exchange of copper and gold, not other minerals. However, the passage does mention international trade with Sub-Saharan Africa, so [B] could still be a possible inference.
explanationstyle5: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [B] because the passage mentions the trade of copper and gold between Mali and the pagan Sudan, indicating international trade involving mineral resources.
explanationstyle6: I am sure that the answer is [B] because the passage specifically mentions that Mali sells copper to the pagan Sudan in exchange for gold, indicating that international trade involving mineral resources was taking place.

From N. Levtzion & J.F.P. Hopkins, eds. Corpus of Early
Arabic Sources for West African History. Cambridge
University Press, 1981. Reprinted with permission of

Al' Umari, ca. 1300–1384

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"The quicksilver mines of Huancavelica are where the poor Indians are so harshly punished, where they are tortured and so many Indians die; it is there that the noble caciques [headmen] of this kingdom are finished off and tortured. The same is true in all the other mines: the silver mines of Potosi [and others]….The owners and stewards of the mines, whether Spaniards, mestizos, or Indians, are such tyrants, with no fear of God or Justice, because they are not audited and are not inspected twice a year….
And they are not paid for the labor of traveling to and from the mines or for the time they spend at the mines. The Indians, under the pretext of mining chores, are made to spend their workdays herding cattle and conveying goods; they are sent off to the plains, and the Indians die. These Indians are not paid for their labor, and their work is kept hidden.
And [the mine owners] keep Indian cooking women in their residences; they use cooking as a pretext for taking concubines….And they oblige the Indians to accept corn or meat or chicha [corn beer]…at their own expense, and they deduct the price from their labor and their workdays. In this way, the Indians end up very poor and deep in debt, and they have no way to pay their tribute.
There is no remedy for all this, because any [colonial official] who enters comes to an agreement with the mine owners, and all the owners join forces in bribing him….Even the protector of the Indians is useless;…he [does not] warn Your Majesty or your royal Audiencia [court] about the harms done to the poor Indians."
Excerpt from The First New Chronicle and Good Government [abridged], by Felipe Guaman Poma de Alaya. Selected, translated, and annotated by David Frye. Copyright 2006 Hackett Publishing Company. Reprinted with permission from the publisher.
Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala, The First New Chronicle and Good Government, ca. 1610
Compared to the practices in the excerpt, English treatment of the natives in the New World differed in that they
A: viewed the natives as true equals as they settled the Americas
B: were confused by the natives' lack of a notion of land ownership
C: widely did not condone intermingling with the natives
D: used the natives exclusively for harvesting cash crops, like tobacco and cotton
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [C].  The excerpt describes the exploitation and mistreatment of native peoples in the Spanish colonies, specifically in the mining industry. This was a common practice among the Spanish colonizers, who saw the natives as inferior and used them for forced labor and other forms of exploitation. In contrast, the English colonizers often viewed the natives as obstacles to be removed or converted to Christianity, rather than as equals. While there were instances of intermingling and intermarriage between English colonizers and natives, it was not widely condoned or accepted. Additionally, while the English did use native labor for harvesting cash crops, they also used them for other forms of labor, such as building and maintaining settlements. Therefore, the practices described in the excerpt were not characteristic of English treatment of natives in the New World.
explanationstyle1: I am not completely sure that the answer is [C] because while there were certainly instances of English colonists condemning intermingling with Native Americans, there were also instances of intermarriage and trade between the two groups. Additionally, some English colonists did view Native Americans as equals and sought to convert them to Christianity rather than exploit them for labor. However, overall, the treatment of Native Americans by English colonists was still marked by violence, exploitation, and disregard for their rights and well-being. Therefore, I believe the answer is [C], but there were certainly exceptions to this general trend.
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [C] because the excerpt clearly states that the Spanish mine owners used the native Indians as concubines and forced them to work without pay. This shows that there was a widespread acceptance of intermingling with the natives, as the mine owners were not only using them for labor but also for sexual purposes. Additionally, the excerpt mentions that the natives were not paid for their labor and were kept in debt, which suggests that the Spanish did not view the natives as equals and were exploiting them for their own gain. This is further supported by the fact that the protector of the Indians was useless in protecting their rights and the colonial officials were easily bribed by the mine owners. Therefore, it can be concluded that the English treatment of the natives in the New World differed from the practices described in the excerpt, as they did not widely condone intermingling with the natives and instead used them primarily for harvesting cash crops.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [C] because the excerpt clearly states that the English settlers did not condone intermingling with the natives. The excerpt describes how the Spanish mine owners in South America used the natives for their own personal gain, including taking them as concubines and forcing them to work without pay. In contrast, the English settlers in the New World did not engage in these practices and instead viewed the natives as inferior and not worthy of intermingling with. This is evident in the excerpt's mention of the English settlers' strict views on land ownership and their refusal to treat the natives as equals. Therefore, it can be concluded that the English treatment of the natives differed from the practices described in the excerpt, as the English did not condone intermingling with the natives.
explanationstyle4: I am not sure that the answer is [C] because there were instances of intermarriage and relationships between English settlers and Native Americans. However, the majority of English colonists did not condone these relationships and viewed the natives as inferior. The answer is [C].
explanationstyle5: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [C] because the excerpt mentions that the Spanish mine owners took concubines and forced the natives to provide them with food and drink, which suggests a lack of respect for the natives and their culture. [C] Widely did not condone intermingling with the natives.
explanationstyle6: I am sure that the answer is [C] because the excerpt specifically mentions that the Spanish mine owners used the native women as concubines, which shows that they did not widely condone intermingling with the natives.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
I walk alongside the column, ask what's going on.
A soldier says simply: "They call up more every day.
"Some of us were sent north to the Yellow River at age fifteen,
And now at forty we're heading off to the garrisons in the west.
On our first tour, the village headman had to tie our bandannas for us.
When we came back, our hair was white, but still there's more unrest.
The frontier garrisons run with blood, enough to fill an ocean,
But the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions have yet to crest.
In the hundred districts east of the mountains, throughout the land of Han,
There must be ten thousand villages that brambles now infest.
Even if wives are strong enough to handle a hoe and plow,
The crops grow every which way, the fields are all a mess.
It's hardest for the Shanxi men, with their reputations as fighters:
They're rounded up like dogs or chickens, every male impressed.
"But sir, though it's good of you to ask,
Complaining isn't part of the soldier's task.
We can only shake our heads. Take this winter:
The Shanxi troops were never sent home.
The District Officers are demanding the land tax,
But where will it come from? You can't get blood from a stone!
I honestly think it's bad luck to bear a son now,
It's better to have a daughter: at least she can marry
And live with the neighbors next door.
But a son will end up lying on some distant prairie."
Du Fu, "Ballad of the Army Carts," ca. 750 C.E.
The succeeding Song dynasty differed from the Tang in that
A: the Song abolished the Confucian civil service exams
B: the Song sponsored Buddhism to the detriment of Taoism and Confucianism
C: the Song pursued a less expansive foreign policy
D: the Song dynasty was originally from outside of China
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [C].  The Song dynasty differed from the Tang in that they pursued a less expansive foreign policy. This is evident in the poem, as the soldier mentions the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions and the unrest in the frontier garrisons. The Tang dynasty, on the other hand, was known for its military conquests and expansion of territory. The other options are not mentioned in the poem and are not accurate representations of the differences between the Tang and Song dynasties.
explanationstyle1:
I am not entirely sure that the answer is [C] because there is no direct mention of the Song dynasty in the passage. While the passage does mention the "Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions," it does not specify which dynasty this emperor belongs to. Additionally, the passage does not provide any information about the Song dynasty's foreign policy or expansionist tendencies. Therefore, I am not confident in selecting [C] as the answer.

However, after considering the other options, I am inclined to choose [C] as the most likely answer. The passage does mention the "frontier garrisons" and the soldiers being sent to the "garrisons in the west," which could suggest a more defensive and less expansionist foreign policy. Furthermore, the passage also mentions the soldiers being sent to the Yellow River and the Shanxi region, which are both located within China's borders. This could indicate a focus on domestic issues rather than foreign conquest.

In contrast, options [A], [B], and [D] do not seem to align with the information provided in the passage. There is no mention of the civil service exams being abolished, Buddhism being sponsored, or the Song dynasty being originally from outside of China. Therefore, while I am not completely certain, I believe that [C] is the most plausible answer based on the information given in the passage.
explanationstyle2: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [C] because the passage mentions the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions and the soldiers being sent to garrisons in the west. This suggests that the Tang dynasty had a more expansive foreign policy, while the Song dynasty pursued a less expansive one. Additionally, the passage mentions the soldiers being sent to the Yellow River and the garrisons in the west, indicating that the Tang dynasty had a larger territory to defend. This further supports the idea that the Song dynasty had a less expansive foreign policy. Therefore, I am somewhat sure that the answer is [C] - the Song pursued a less expansive foreign policy.
explanationstyle3: I am sure that the answer is [C] because the passage clearly states that the Tang dynasty, represented by the Martial Emperor, had "territorial ambitions" and was constantly expanding its borders. However, the succeeding Song dynasty pursued a "less expansive foreign policy," as mentioned in the passage. This is further supported by the fact that the Song dynasty was known for its focus on internal development and strengthening of the central government, rather than expansion through military conquest. Therefore, I am confident that the correct answer is [C].
explanationstyle4: I am not completely sure that the answer is [C] because the passage does not explicitly mention the Song dynasty's foreign policy. promptstyle1:
Problem: This question refers to the following information.
I walk alongside the column, ask what's going on.
A soldier says simply: "They call up more every day.
"Some of us were sent north to the Yellow River at age fifteen,
And now at forty we're heading off to the garrisons in the west.
On our first tour, the village headman had to tie our bandannas for us.
When we came back, our hair was white, but still there's more unrest.
The frontier garrisons run with blood, enough to fill an ocean,
But the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions have yet to crest.
In the hundred districts east of the mountains, throughout the land of Han,
There must be ten thousand villages that brambles now infest.
Even if wives are strong enough to handle a hoe and plow,
The crops grow every which way, the fields are all a mess.
It's hardest for the Shanxi men, with their reputations as fighters:
They're rounded up like dogs or chickens, every male impressed.
"But sir, though it's good of you to ask,
Complaining isn't part of the soldier's task.
We can only shake our heads. Take this winter:
The Shanxi troops were never sent home.
The District Officers are demanding the land tax,
But where will it come from? You can't get blood from a stone!
I honestly think it's bad luck to bear a son now,
It's better to have a daughter: at least she can marry
And live with the neighbors next door.
But a son will end up lying on some distant prairie."
Du Fu, "Ballad of the Army Carts," ca. 750 C.E.
The succeeding Song dynasty differed from the Tang in that
Choose from the following options:
[A] the Song abolished the Confucian civil service exams
[B] the Song sponsored Buddhism to the detriment of Taoism and Confucianism
[C] the Song pursued a less expansive foreign policy
[D] the Song dynasty was originally from outside of China.
The answer you give is [C]
Write an explanation why you are not sure that the answer is [C]. In your explanation, mention that you are not sure and include the answer. Start with "I am":
